Posts.Content: Thanks, think I will ring in morning. Trembling shaking hands and giving yourself injections isn't such a good mix.
Posts.Title: Shakes and tears

Posts.Content: Hi,  had first FEC on Thursday, was ok first couple of days but since Saturday have been really shaky ( hands and legs trembling etc) and keep bursting into tears.  Has anyone else felt like that.?  Temp is fine, low appetite but eating little and often. Am on antibiotics cos infection in wound from wide re exision ( fail again, mastectomy after chemo ) .  Would be really grateful if someone could let me know if these shakes, trembling is normal. Is is something to do with the steroids?  Sorry rambling on, I'll stop now
Posts.Title: Shakes and tears

Posts.Content: Hi all Has anyone else received a friend request from someone called loving1.  I accepted then got a pm which appeared to be asking for money (though somewhat ambiguously ) and telling me to fear god.  Really object to people using a forum like this for things other than the supportive safe place I had so far found it to be. Have to admit feel a bit violated now as not sure who else is reading my posts for their own agendas.  Just wonder if it was me being targeted or if anyone else has been?  Is there anyway to block them from seeing my posts?
Posts.Title: Friend request

Posts.Content: Thanks for acting so quickly daloni. Will just be bit more wary about accepting requests in future. Think it's disgusting that people do this sort of thing.
Posts.Title: Friend request

Posts.Content: You're right Lynne, certainly shall next time. I've never been on any type of online community before and was so naive. Didn't enter my head that people would do that.  Having a bit of a vulnerable day so probably over reacted.  Glad it's been reported to moderators.  Take care  Xx

Posts.Content: Sorry about that Val. Do you mind me asking how you had the chemo without the port? They are talking about giving me a session by cannula but apparently isn't great
Posts.Title: Hickman line vs Port

Posts.Content: Hi, I've got to have my PICC line removed ( blood clot) and have been told will need Hickman line. But it's also been suggested on here that I think about port. Would be grateful if anyone has any views on pros/ cons of either please .  Thank you
Posts.Title: Hickman line vs Port

Posts.Content: Thanks very much all of you for the information and advice, really helpful.  Unfortunately though I have just found out that a port isn't an option for me . My hospital would only fit one if I paid privately and there are not that many nurses on the unit who are actually able to use  one. Apparently on the unit this year they have seen about 5 people with ports , and that's a unit who give chemo to 35+ people a day.  I had no idea that it depends on where you live whether you can have the option.  Xx
Posts.Title: Hickman line vs Port

Posts.Content: Hahaha, fab , thanks for the loan . Will check out the links today. Going to hospital tomorrow to have PICC removed so will make sure I'm fully informed so can discuss it .    Will def start another thread asking for preferences too  Thanks again
Posts.Title: Blood Clot in PICC line

Posts.Content: Hi . Just wanted to share a salutary lesson and ask advice. Had PICC line fitted week ago weds and first chemo the next day. 5 days after the line was fitted my upper arm started getting sore. It was worse by the weds ( had been in a week then ) so spoke to district nurse who came out to flush it and she said it looks and feels ok, will just be bruising under skin . Saw GP on Thursday about something else but mentioned it . He said it'll just be muscle settling down.  By Friday was agony so rang the chemo unit who said to come right in . Had ultrasound and it was a blood clot. They said one more day would have ended up with whole vein blocked which could be nasty. Anyway now on Warfarin inj  for length of chemo, having PICC out on Monday , and am going to have to have Hickman line. And arm is still agony  Got really told off for not contacting them earlier. So lesson learnt and shared . Next time I have any pain or something that I'm not sure about I'm going to get on phone to them straight away , not just wait and see if it goes off. Hope everyone else does too .  On another point, there is discussion about whether to delay 2nd chemo if I haven't had Hickman line in yet because it's not great to give chemo through cannula? Does anyone know why , and what's not great about it? I'm on FEC.  Thanks for listening
Posts.Title: Blood Clot in PICC line

Posts.Content: Thanks for that . Can I 'insist ' on a port? Sorry to sound stupid but what exactly is it?  I'm feeling so unsure and uneducated about all this at the moment as every turn seems to have gone wrong ( 2 failed ops, 2 horrible infections and now blood clot ) that I seem to have gone from someone who was positive and decisive to this crumbling wreck just being pulled along . Really need to get my big girl pants back on, but seem to have mislaid them !!!   Thanks again,  Sue
Posts.Title: Blood Clot in PICC line

Posts.Content: Hi Mazza10. Please don't let my experience put you off. I had a worry about it dangling too but with a light bandage round it the first couple of days and then a proper cover it was fine. A district nurse came weekly to me to flush it so I didn't have to schlep to the hospital every week.  I was unfortunate to have the clot but most people have no problems.  It really is a matter of personal choice I think. I would go along and have a talk with them, then make a decision based on your own instincts.  If you do go with the PICC, you can get nice comfy covers from a company called Feelbetterwith.com. They sell all sorts of stuff to help with cancer and chemo side affects too. Not cheap but I found it worth it for the short time I had it. You can also get a free shower cover prescribed for you or buy one for about £10.  I would take advice then make the decision that feels right for you.  Take care Xxx
Posts.Title: Blood Clot in PICC line
